variant.question:
Given
 Runway direction (M) 050° 

Maxtailwind component 10 kts
 Current wind direction (M) 170° 

Calculate the maximum allowed wind speed for the take-off
The take-off distance available is:

options.text: the length of the take-off run available plus the length of the clearway available.
the runway length plus half of the clearway.
the total runway length, without clearway even if this one exists.

variant.question: If you were performing the downwind leg at the Addison airport in Texas with a strong tailwind, after turning to final what must you do?

options.text: Increase engine power to stay on the correct glide path because the headwind will cause your glide path angle to increase.
Increase engine power to stay on the correct glide path because the headwind will cause your glide path angle to decrease.
Decrease engine power to stay on the correct glide path because the headwind will cause your glide path angle to decrease.
Decrease engine power to stay on the correct glide path because the headwind will cause your glide path angle to increase.

When compared to still air conditions, a constant headwind component:

options.text: increases the angle of flight path during climb.
increases the best rate of climb.

variant.question:
Given
 TORA 3 380 m
 Clearway 780 m
 Stopway 1 250 m
 What is the TODA if the pilot wants to calculate the RLLTOM (Runway Length Limited Take-Off Mass) for an unbalanced field?
To achieve the maximum range over ground with headwind the airspeed should be...

options.text: higher compared to the speed for maximum range cruise with no wind.
equal to the speed for maximum range cruise with no wind.
reduced to the gust penetration speed.
lower compared to the speed for maximum range cruise with no wind.

variant.question:
To determine the Runway length Limited Take-Off Mass (RLTOM) for an unbalanced field, what is the TODA to be used for a Class A aircraft given the following data?
  • TORA: 2380 m
  • Stopway: 1470 m
  • Clearway: 560 m
Accelerate stop distance available (ASDA) is the length of the

options.text: take-off run available plus the length of provided stopway.
take-off run available plus the length of provided stopway and clearway.
take-off run available plus the length of provided clearway.
runway available plus the length of provided stopway.

variant.question: You are on the approach to an airfield where there is a 30 kt crosswind. You are maintaining a speed of 180 kt CAS and a rate of descent of - 1 200 fpm. During one the final turn the 30 kt crosswind turns into a headwind. What should your actions be to maintain the correct approach path?

options.text: Reduce the rate of descent and maintain 180 kt CAS.
Increase the rate of descent and maintain 180 kt CAS.
Increase the rate of descent and increase the speed above 180 kt CAS.
Reduce the rate of descent and increase the speed above 180 kt CAS.

variant.question:
Given

- Runway direction (M): 050°
- Max. tailwind component: 10 kts
- Current wind direction (M): 170°

Calculate the maximum allowed wind speed for the take-off:

Refer to figure 032-21.
The distances X, Y, Z and W are defined as:
A constant headwind:

options.text: increases the angle of the descent flight path.
increases the descent distance over ground.

variant.question: A jet aircraft is cruising at the speed for maximum range in still air conditions. The aircraft suddenly encounters a strong headwind, what action should the pilot take?

options.text: Fly faster than the maximum range cruise speed for no wind
Fly a slower speed than maximum range for no wind.
Slow to the speed for maximum endurance
Fly the same speed for maximum range in no wind

variant.question: A constant headwind component

options.text: increases the angle of flight path during climb.
increases the best rate of climb.

variant.question: During climb to the cruising level, a headwind component

options.text: decreases the ground distance flown during that climb.
increases the amount of fuel for the climb.

variant.question: Approaching in turbulent wind conditions during manual flight requires

Calculate the TODA, given the following runway information.TORA: 2 380 ft 
 Stopway: 560 ft 
 Clearway: 1 570 ft

Consider EASA AIR OPS regulations PART-CAT
What is correct about the TOD and ASDA?

options.text: If there is no stopway or clearway, the TOD × 1.25 shall not exceed the TORA.
If there is a stopway or a clearway and the runway is wet, the TOD × 1.15 shall not exceed the TORA.
If there is a stopway or a clearway and the runway slopes up or down, the TOD should be increased by 5% of the TORA.
If there is a stopway or a clearway, the ASDA shall not exceed the TORA.

variant.question: What will be the effect on the range, if an aircraft experiences a headwind component of 5 kt?

options.text: Range stays the same, SFC will decrease.
Range stays the same, SFC will increase.

variant.question: If there is a tailwind

options.text: the minimum drag speed is not affected.
the minimum drag speed is decreased by the same velocity as the wind.
the minimum drag speed is increased.
the minimum drag speed is decreased.

The 22 kt headwind on Rwy 07 means the pilot should continue the approach and land on Rwy 07.
